repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Prince - Public Resource
            Management Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Resource Management Credit
            Project for Sao Tome and Prince had the following ratings:
            the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was
            likely, the institutional development impact was modest, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory.
            The lessons learned indicate that it is important to ensure
            that any policy reform has government ownership. Without
            government commitment, it is difficult to achieve
            development objectives. During project preparation, special
            attention should be given to the project's content and
            how it fits within the context of prevailing weak
            institutional capacity and the level of political
            volatility. The Letter of Development Policy (LDP) should
            have been much less ambitious, and more focused, and the
            project design should have been much simpler. Consideration
            should be given whether an adjustment operation is the right
            instrument for a country like Sao Tome and Principe given
            its political volatility and weak institutional capacity.
            The program showed an unusual phenomenon that while the
            adjustment operation did not perform well, the Technical
            Assistance (TA) part of the program did well. The linkage
            between the Credit and the TA activities was not strongly
            established at the beginning and the TA was not programmed
            closely/in a timely manner to support the reform program
            sufficiently. Increased supervision funding would have been
            useful so as to undertake multisectoral and more in-depth
            supervision. The government should ensure that capacity that
            has already been built with the help of the project will
            remain within MOF, and that staff, who were involved with
            the project, are not shifted to other places. The
            collaboration of the Bank with the IMF had a positive impact
            on the outcome of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Public Resource
            Management Credit and Technical Assistance Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Resource Management Credit
            (PRMC) will assist in consolidating Sao Tome and
            Principe's macroeconomic stability, and attain
            competitiveness, while its supporting operation, the Public
            Resource Management Technical Assistance Project (PRMTA) was
            designed to provide the technical support, training, and
            equipment to implement policy measures, currently proposed
            under the reform program supported by the PRMC. The PRMTA
            will also implement sectoral, sub-sectoral, and specific
            studies, namely, through the financing of a study fund for
            these, and/or simulation models, required for the
            preparation of the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper, and,
            will develop an agenda for macroeconomic, and sectoral
            policy reforms. The operations will benefit the
            implementation of tariff reforms, ensuring a harmonious
            development of the revised tariff system, with the common
            tariff of the Central African Economic and Monetary
            Community, and the Western African Economic and Monetary
            Union. In turn, private investments flows and improved
            resource mobilization, will impact economic diversification,
            and external trade, thereby enhancing productivity of public
            resources. However, the proposed agenda may face resistance,
            and social unrest, and, other risks are posed by low
            institutional capacity, limited donor commitment, and a weak
            private sector, although the Government is committed to
            outweigh these risks.
